description: To go (somewhere) in order to do an action
formation: Verb (ます-stem) + に + 行きます
explanation:
### Name
- Vます形＋に行く

### Meaning and function
- “Go (somewhere) in order to do V.” States the purpose of movement.

### Form and templates
- Core
  - V(stem/連用形) ＋ に ＋ 行く／行きます
- With destination
  - N(place) ＋ に／へ ＋ V(stem) ＋ に ＋ 行く／行きます
- With objects/recipients etc.
  - N(object) ＋ を ＋ V(stem) ＋ に ＋ 行く／行きます
  - Other arguments of the purpose verb (recipient に, instrument で, time に, etc.) come before V(stem)＋に
- Alternatives
  - V(stem) ＋ に ＋ 来る／帰る (come/return in order to do V)
- Particle requirements and ordering
  - The に after V(stem) is the purpose marker (required; cannot be へ or で)
  - Destination uses に or へ (use one; both are acceptable for direction/goal)
  - Typical order: [destination] → [other arguments] → [V(stem)＋に] → [行く/来る/帰る]
    - Destination and purpose chunks can swap, but the above is the most common and clear
- Conjugation notes
  - Conjugate 行く／来る／帰る for tense/politeness: 行きます／行きました／行かない／行きません, etc.
  - The purpose verb appears in ます-stem (連用形). For する-verbs, use し (e.g., …しに行く). Some activity nouns also allow N に 行く (no する), depending on the word.

### Usage notes and constraints
- Register/frequency
  - Very common and neutral; used in both casual (行く) and polite (行きます) styles
- Semantic constraints
  - Used only with motion verbs (行く・来る・帰る) to express purpose tied to physical movement
  - The purpose must be an action verb (not adjectives/states). Avoid using pure motion verbs as the purpose (i.e., “go in order to go”)
  - Past forms usually imply you went with that intention; completion of the purpose action is not guaranteed unless context says so
- Scope and stacking of particles
  - Multiple に can appear with different roles (time に, destination に, purpose に); this is normal in Japanese
- Orthographic variants
  - 行く／いく, 来る／くる are both seen; kanji is standard in formal writing, kana is common in casual text. The particle へ is written へ but pronounced [え].

### Common mistakes
- Using V(dictionary)＋に行く; the purpose must be V(stem)＋に行く
- Replacing the purpose に with へ or で after the stem (V(stem)＋へ/で＋行く is incorrect for purpose)
- Negating the purpose verb before に (V(ない)＋に行く is ungrammatical). Negate the motion verb instead (…に行かない/行きません) or use 〜ないで行く for “go without doing”
- Marking the destination with を; destination takes に/へ. Use を only for the object of the purpose verb
- Doubling destination particles (へに/にへ). Choose one destination marker

### Related grammar
- V(辞書形) ＋ ために: General “in order to” purpose; not limited to motion verbs. Slightly more formal/literary than V(stem)＋に with 行く/来る
- N(place) ＋ に／へ ＋ 行く: “Go to a place” (no stated purpose). Add V(stem)＋に to express the purpose
- V(て) ＋ いく／くる: Movement away from/toward the speaker after or along with an action; expresses direction over time, not purpose
- N(サ変名詞) ＋ に 行く / N ＋ しに 行く: Purpose expressed by an activity noun; some nouns appear naturally without する, others prefer しに depending on the word

examples.jp: 図書館へ本を返しに行きます。
examples.en: I will go to the library to return a book.

examples.jp: 朝、駅に友だちを早く迎えに行く。
examples.en: In the morning, I’ll go to the station early to pick up a friend.

examples.jp: 今夜、一緒にラーメンを食べに行きませんか。
examples.en: Shall we go eat ramen tonight?

examples.jp: 昨日、母に会いに実家へ行きました。
examples.en: Yesterday I went to my parents’ home to see my mother.

examples.jp: お金がないから、映画を見にいかない。
examples.en: I won’t go to watch a movie because I have no money.

examples.jp: 雨だったので、公園へ散歩に行きませんでした。
examples.en: Because it was rainy, I didn’t go for a walk in the park.

examples.jp: このあと、コピーを取りにくる？
examples.en: Are you coming to make some copies after this?

examples.jp: 明日の朝7時に駅へ切符を買いに行きます。
examples.en: I’ll go to the station at 7 a.m. tomorrow to buy tickets.

examples.jp: 京都に写真を撮りに行くつもりはない。
examples.en: I don’t plan to go to Kyoto to take photos.

examples.jp: 犬に薬を飲ませに家に帰ります。
examples.en: I’m going home to give the dog its medicine.

examples.jp: 彼はわざわざ謝りに来なかった。
examples.en: He didn’t bother to come to apologize.

examples.jp: 午後、体育館に練習しに行きます。
examples.en: In the afternoon, I’ll go to the gym to practice.

examples.jp: 先生が資料を渡しにくるらしい。
examples.en: It seems the teacher will come to hand out the materials.

examples.jp: パンを買いに行く人を見かけた。
examples.en: I saw a person who was going to buy bread.

examples.jp: 昼休みに、会社の近くのカフェへ勉強しに行った。
examples.en: During lunch break, I went to a café near the office to study.

examples.jp: 彼は部長に相談しに来ましたか。
examples.en: Did he come to consult with the department manager?

examples.jp: 子どもたちは川へ魚を釣りに行ってもいいですか。
examples.en: May the children go to the river to fish?

examples.jp: 今日はカメラを持って、紅葉を撮りに山へ行きました。
examples.en: Today I brought my camera and went to the mountains to shoot the autumn leaves.

examples.jp: 台所へ包丁で野菜を切りに行く。
examples.en: I’m going to the kitchen to cut vegetables with a knife.

examples.jp: 彼女は家に夕飯を食べに帰らなかった。
examples.en: She didn’t go home to eat dinner.

negativeExamples.en: I go to school every morning.

negativeExamples.jp: 夏に海へ行く予定です。
negativeExamples.en: I plan to go to the beach in summer.
Are you coming to my friend’s house?

negativeExamples.jp: 映画を見るために行きました。
negativeExamples.en: I went in order to watch a movie.

negativeExamples.jp: 帰りにスーパーに寄った。
negativeExamples.en: I stopped by the supermarket on the way back.
Don’t go any farther from here.

negativeExamples.jp: 本を読むのにこの公園は静かでいい。
negativeExamples.en: This park is nice and quiet for reading books.

negativeExamples.jp: あの店は行くのが難しい。
negativeExamples.en: It’s hard to get to that shop.

negativeExamples.jp: 楽しみにして行きます。
negativeExamples.en: I’ll go looking forward to it.
